original_data.Title: Natural Language Processing Specialization
original_data.Short Intro: Break into NLP. Master cutting-edge NLP techniques through four hands-on courses! Updated with the latest techniques in October '21.
original_data.Skills: Word2vec, Machine Translation, Sentiment Analysis, Transformers, Attention Models, Word Embeddings, Locality-Sensitive Hashing, Vector Space Models, Parts-of-Speech Tagging, N-gram Language Models, Autocorrect, Word Embedding,

unified_data.title: Natural Language Processing Specialization
unified_data.description: Break into NLP. Master cutting-edge NLP techniques through four hands-on courses! Updated with the latest techniques in October '21.
unified_data.prerequisites: Basic Python programming, probability and statistics, linear algebra, and some machine learning fundamentals are recommended.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Master cutting-edge NLP techniques, including Word2vec, transformers, sentiment analysis, and machine translation. Gain hands-on experience with word embeddings, attention models, and vector space models.
unified_data.price: Coursera subscriptions vary. Check Coursera for current pricing (likely part of a monthly subscription).

original_data.Title: Introduction to Machine Learning
original_data.Short Intro: This course will provide you a foundational understanding of machine learning models (logistic regression, multilayer perceptrons, convolutional neural networks, natural language processing, etc.) as well as demonstrate how these models can solve complex problems in a variety of industries, from medical diagnostics to image recognition to text prediction. In addition, we have designed practice exercises that will give you hands-on experience implementing these data science models on data sets. These practice exercises will teach you how to implement machine learning algorithms with PyTorch, open source libraries used by leading tech companies in the machine learning field (e.g., Google, NVIDIA, CocaCola, eBay, Snapchat, Uber and many more).
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, German, Russian, English, Spanish
original_data.Skills: Natural Language Processing,Convolutional Neural Network,Machine Learning,Python Programming,pytorch,

unified_data.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
unified_data.description: This course will provide you a foundational understanding of machine learning models (logistic regression, multilayer perceptrons, convolutional neural networks, natural language processing, etc.) as well as demonstrate how these models can solve complex problems in a variety of industries, from medical diagnostics to image recognition to text prediction. In addition, we have designed practice exercises that will give you hands-on experience implementing these data science models on data sets. These practice exercises will teach you how to implement machine learning algorithms with PyTorch, open source libraries used by leading tech companies in the machine learning field (e.g., Google, NVIDIA, CocaCola, eBay, Snapchat, Uber and many more).
prerequisites: Basic Python programming knowledge, familiarity with data structures, and a foundational understanding of mathematics (linear algebra and calculus) are recommended.
learning_outcomes: Gain a foundational understanding of various machine learning models. Learn to implement these models using PyTorch on real-world datasets. Develop practical skills in solving complex problems across diverse industries.
unified_data.price: Paid

original_data.Title: Probabilistic Graphical Models 1: Representation
original_data.Short Intro: Probabilistic graphical models (PGMs) are a rich framework for encoding probability distributions over complex domains: joint (multivariate) distributions over large numbers of random variables that interact with each other. These representations sit at the intersection of statistics and computer science, relying on concepts from probability theory, graph algorithms, machine learning, and more. They are the basis for the state-of-the-art methods in a wide variety of applications, such as medical diagnosis, image understanding, speech recognition, natural language processing, and many, many more. They are also a foundational tool in formulating many machine learning problems.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, German, Russian, English, Spanish
original_data.Skills: Bayesian Network,Graphical Model,Markov Random Field,

unified_data.title: Probabilistic Graphical Models 1: Representation
unified_data.description: Probabilistic graphical models (PGMs) are a rich framework for encoding probability distributions over complex domains: joint (multivariate) distributions over large numbers of random variables that interact with each other. These representations sit at the intersection of statistics and computer science, relying on concepts from probability theory, graph algorithms, machine learning, and more. They are the basis for the state-of-the-art methods in a wide variety of applications, such as medical diagnosis, image understanding, speech recognition, natural language processing, and many, many more. They are also a foundational tool in formulating many machine learning problems.
prerequisites: Probability theory, basic graph algorithms, and introductory machine learning concepts.
Linear algebra and calculus are helpful.
learning_outcomes: Understand and represent complex probability distributions using PGMs.
Apply PGMs in diverse fields like medical diagnosis and NLP.
Formulate machine learning problems using PGM frameworks.
unified_data.price: Coursera offers courses for free with limited access. Paid subscriptions provide full access and certificates.

original_data.Title: JSON and Natural Language Processing in PostgreSQL
original_data.Short Intro: Within this course, you’ll learn about how PostgreSQL creates and uses inverted indexes for JSON and natural language content. We will use various sources of data for our databases, including access to an online API and spidering its data and storing the data in a JSON column in PostgreSQL.  Students will explore how full-text inverted indexes are structured.  Students will build their own inverted indexes and then make use of PostgreSQL built-in capabilities to support full-text indexes.

unified_data.title: JSON and Natural Language Processing in PostgreSQL
unified_data.description: Within this course, you’ll learn about how PostgreSQL creates and uses inverted indexes for JSON and natural language content. We will use various sources of data for our databases, including access to an online API and spidering its data and storing the data in a JSON column in PostgreSQL.  Students will explore how full-text inverted indexes are structured.  Students will build their own inverted indexes and then make use of PostgreSQL built-in capabilities to support full-text indexes.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Learn how PostgreSQL uses inverted indexes for JSON and natural language data. Build custom indexes and leverage PostgreSQL's built-in full-text indexing capabilities using data from APIs and web spidering.
unified_data.price: Paid

unified_data.learning_outcomes: Learn to implement hidden Markov models, use Viterbi algorithm for part-of-speech tagging, apply N-gram models, and build autocorrect algorithms using probabilistic techniques.
unified_data.price: Coursera offers a free audit option. Paid options, such as a subscription, may apply for graded assignments and a certificate.

original_data.Title: Applied Text Mining in Python
original_data.Short Intro: This course will introduce the learner to text mining and text manipulation basics. The course begins with an understanding of how text is handled by python, the structure of text both to the machine and to humans, and an overview of the nltk framework for manipulating text. The second week focuses on common manipulation needs, including regular expressions (searching for text), cleaning text, and preparing text for use by machine learning processes. The third week will apply basic natural language processing methods to text, and demonstrate how text classification is accomplished. The final week will explore more advanced methods for detecting the topics in documents and grouping them by similarity (topic modelling).
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, Korean, German, Russian, English, Spanish
original_data.Skills: Natural Language Toolkit (NLTK),Text Mining,Python Programming,Natural Language Processing,

unified_data.title: Applied Text Mining in Python
unified_data.description: This course will introduce the learner to text mining and text manipulation basics. The course begins with an understanding of how text is handled by python, the structure of text both to the machine and to humans, and an overview of the nltk framework for manipulating text. The second week focuses on common manipulation needs, including regular expressions (searching for text), cleaning text, and preparing text for use by machine learning processes. The third week will apply basic natural language processing methods to text, and demonstrate how text classification is accomplished. The final week will explore more advanced methods for detecting the topics in documents and grouping them by similarity (topic modelling).
prerequisites: Basic Python programming knowledge, familiarity with data structures.
learning_outcomes: Understand text handling in Python, apply regular expressions for text searching and cleaning, perform text classification, and use topic modeling techniques.
unified_data.price: Paid

original_data.Title: Computational Social Science Capstone Project
original_data.Short Intro: CONGRATULATIONS! Not only did you accomplish to finish our intellectual tour de force, but, by now, you also already have all required skills to execute a comprehensive multi-method workflow of computational social science. We will put these skills to work in this final integrative lab, where we are bringing it all together. We scrape data from a social media site (drawing on the skills obtained in the 1st course of this specialization). We then analyze the collected data by visualizing the resulting networks (building on the skills obtained in the 3rd course). We analyze some key aspects of it in depth, using machine learning powered natural language processing (putting to work the insights obtained during the 2nd course). Finally, we use a computer simulation model to explore possible generative mechanism and scrutinize aspects that we did not find in our empirical reality, but that help us to improve this aspect of society (drawing on the skills obtained during the 4th course of this specialization). The result is the first glimpse at a new way of doing social science in a digital age: computational social science. Congratulations! Having done all of this yourself, you can consider yourself a fledgling computational social scientist!
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: French, Portuguese (European), Russian, English, Spanish

prerequisites: Completion of the Computational Social Science specialization courses on Coursera or equivalent knowledge.
Basic understanding of social science concepts and research methods.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Apply a comprehensive multi-method workflow to a computational social science project. Scrape data, visualize networks, use machine learning for NLP, and create computer simulation models to analyze and improve aspects of society.
unified_data.price: Part of a paid specialization, individual course price may vary. Free audit available.

original_data.Title: Natural Language Processing in Microsoft Azure

original_data.Title: Applying Data Analytics in Accounting
original_data.Short Intro: This course explores business analytic applications in accounting. First, it presents a survey of technology topics in accounting, including process mining, blockchain and applications in audit, tax, and assurance. Next, the course explores visualization and basic analytics in audit and control testing using R and Alteryx. Next, the course examines the uses of text analysis in accounting and conducts text analysis using R and RStudio. Finally, the course examines robot process automation in general using UiPath and its applications in accounting.
original_data.Skills: Natural Language Processing,robotic process automation,Analytics,Data Analysis,Accounting Analytics,
original_data.Instructors: Gies College of Business, University of Illinois

unified_data.title: Applying Data Analytics in Accounting
unified_data.description: This course explores business analytic applications in accounting. Next, the course examines the uses of text analysis in accounting and conducts text analysis using R and RStudio. Finally, the course examines robot process automation in general using UiPath and its applications in accounting.

original_data.Title: Build, Train, and Deploy ML Pipelines using BERT
original_data.Short Intro: In the second course of the Practical Data Science Specialization, you will learn to automate a natural language processing task by building an end-to-end machine learning pipeline using Hugging Face’s highly-optimized implementation of the state-of-the-art BERT algorithm with Amazon SageMaker Pipelines. Your pipeline will first transform the dataset into BERT-readable features and store the features in the Amazon SageMaker Feature Store. It will then fine-tune a text classification model to the dataset using a Hugging Face pre-trained model, which has learned to understand the human language from millions of Wikipedia documents. Finally, your pipeline will evaluate the model’s accuracy and only deploy the model if the accuracy exceeds a given threshold.
original_data.Skills: ML Pipelines and MLOps,Model Training and Deployment with BERT,Model Debugging and Evaluation,Feature engineering and feature store,Artifact and lineage tracking,

unified_data.title: Build, Train, and Deploy ML Pipelines using BERT
unified_data.description: In the second course of the Practical Data Science Specialization, you will learn to automate a natural language processing task by building an end-to-end machine learning pipeline using Hugging Face’s highly-optimized implementation of the state-of-the-art BERT algorithm with Amazon SageMaker Pipelines. Your pipeline will first transform the dataset into BERT-readable features and store the features in the Amazon SageMaker Feature Store. It will then fine-tune a text classification model to the dataset using a Hugging Face pre-trained model, which has learned to understand the human language from millions of Wikipedia documents. Finally, your pipeline will evaluate the model’s accuracy and only deploy the model if the accuracy exceeds a given threshold.
skills: Model Training and Deployment with BERT

original_data.Short Intro: Probabilistic graphical models (PGMs) are a rich framework for encoding probability distributions over complex domains: joint (multivariate) distributions over large numbers of random variables that interact with each other. These representations sit at the intersection of statistics and computer science, relying on concepts from probability theory, graph algorithms, machine learning, and more. They are the basis for the state-of-the-art methods in a wide variety of applications, such as medical diagnosis, image understanding, speech recognition, natural language processing, and many, many more. They are also a foundational tool in formulating many machine learning problems.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, German, Russian, English, Spanish
original_data.Skills: Bayesian Network,Graphical Model,Markov Random Field,

original_data.Title: Clinical Natural Language Processing
original_data.Short Intro: This course teaches you the fundamentals of clinical natural language processing (NLP). In this course you will learn the basic linguistic principals underlying NLP, as well as how to write regular expressions and handle text data in R. You will also learn practical techniques for text processing to be able to extract information from clinical notes.  Finally, you will have a chance to put your skills to the test with a real-world practical application where you develop text processing algorithms to identify diabetic complications from clinical notes. You will complete this work using a free, online computational environment for data science hosted by our Industry Partner Google Cloud.

original_data.Title: Artificial Intelligence Engineer
original_data.Short Intro: Accelerate your career with this Master's in Artificial Intelligence in conjunction with IBM. This program includes industry-relevant courses, such as Data Science with Python, Machine Learning, Deep Learning, NLP, and Chat GPT and also features hackathons and AMA sessions hosted by IBM. Get job-ready in the AI domain with Capstone projects, practical labs, live sessions, and hands-on projects.
original_data.Course Type: Ranked #1 Masters in Artificial Intelligence Program by Career Karma

original_data.Title: Become a Natural Language Processing Expert
original_data.Short Intro: Master the skills to get computers to understand, process, and manipulate human language. Build models on real data, and get hands-on experience with sentiment analysis, machine translation, and more.
original_data.Prequisites: This program requires experience with Python, statistics, machine learning, and deep learning.
original_data.What you learn: Learn cutting-edge natural language processing techniques to process speech and analyze text. Build probabilistic and deep learning models, such as hidden Markov models and recurrent neural networks, to teach the computer to do tasks such as speech recognition, machine translation, and more!

unified_data.title: Become a Natural Language Processing Expert

original_data.Title: Data Engineering for Data Scientists
original_data.Short Intro: Learn how to wrangle data on a massive scale! By the end of this course, you’ll be able to pull data from a wide range of sources, store it in a database, and create data pipelines (ETL, NLP, machine learning) that power real-world web applications.
original_data.What you learn: For many companies, data scientists who can also tackle data-engineering problems are worth their weight in gold. In this course, you’ll learn how to unlock data silos, pulling data from multiple sources and pipelining it into usable forms for analysts and top-level decision makers. At the end, you’ll even build an impressive machine-learning-powered web application that has real-world, life-saving significance.
